questions.text: A 25-year old female presents with the lesion shown below in the x-ray. Identify the condition: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) GCT

 

GIANT CELL TUMOUR (GCT)

 

  • They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance.
  • The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone.
  • Although rare in skeletally immature patients, giant cell tumors arise in the metaphysis in this age group.
  • Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex; however, intraarticular extension is rare because the subchondral bone usually remains intact.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Difference between Aneurysmal bone cyst and GCT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermoid cyst. A dermoid cyst is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. These benign tumors are lined by stratified squamous epithelium with mature skin appendages found on their wall and their lumens filled with keratin and hair. Dermoid cysts are considered to be congenital, but not all of them are diagnosed at birth. Only about 40% of dermoid cysts are diagnosed at birth, while about 60% are diagnosed by five years of age. The dermoid cysts usually present within the first year of life and grow slowly. Dermoid cysts occur most commonly on the head and neck. The etiology of dermoid cysts remains mostly unknown. These occur when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development. In the head and neck region, dermoid cysts can most commonly be seen in the frontal, occipital, and supraorbital areas, with the outer third of the eyebrow being the most frequently affected region.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor of distal end radius is always GCT until proven otherwise.
  • Mc site of giant cell tumor is lower end femur.
  • Lower end femur is Mc site for:
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis

questions.text: A 24-year-old man after drinking too much alcohol developed chest pain. X-ray showed pneumomediastinum. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation is a serious condition that can occur spontaneously, often after episodes of severe vomiting or retching, commonly associated with excessive alcohol consumption. This condition can lead to the presence of air in the mediastinum (pneumomediastinum), which can be detected on an X-ray. The classic clinical presentation includes chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema. When the perforation occurs spontaneously, it is known as Boerhaave syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mallory Weiss syndrome: This condition involves a partial tear at the gastroesophageal junction, usually following severe vomiting. It typically presents with hematemesis (vomiting blood) but does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Option C. Pulsion diverticulum: This type of diverticulum is an outpouching of the esophageal wall due to increased intraluminal pressure. While it can cause dysphagia and regurgitation, it does not typically present with pneumomediastinum.

 

Option D. Acute Pericarditis: Acute pericarditis is inflammation of the pericardium and typically presents with sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing or lying down. It does not cause pneumomediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation, often associated with severe vomiting and alcohol consumption, can present with chest pain, pneumomediastinum, and subcutaneous emphysema, and is a medical emergency.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Information Communication Technology based Surveillance system for TB patients under National TB Elimination Program? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nikshay

 

Nikshay is an online software platform used in India for the surveillance of tuberculosis (TB) patients under the National TB Elimination Program. This Information and Communication Technology (ICT)-based system connects all the DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) clinics across the country to a central server managed by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. It allows for real-time data generation and monitoring, providing critical insights into cure rates, incidences of multi-drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB), treatment failures, relapses, and other important metrics. The system's comprehensive data collection capabilities make it an essential tool in the fight against TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DOTS: DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment, Short-course) is a strategy rather than a surveillance system. It involves healthcare workers observing patients take their TB medication to ensure compliance, but it is not a technological platform like Nikshay.

 

Option B. DOTS-99: DOTS-99 is an ICT-based adherence system, not a surveillance system. It is designed to ensure patients adhere to their TB treatment regimen. After taking their medication, patients give a missed call to a toll-free number using their registered mobile number. This system is effective in tracking medication adherence but does not provide the comprehensive surveillance and data management features of Nikshay.

 

Option D. Nischay: "Nischay" is not related to TB surveillance or management. This option does not pertain to any ICT-based system for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay is the ICT-based surveillance system used for TB patients under the National TB Elimination Program in India. It enables real-time data collection and monitoring of TB cases across the country.

questions.text: In the presence of tracheal deviation as indicated on a chest X-ray, which procedure is the most difficult to perform? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

A tracheostomy involves creating an opening through the neck into the trachea, which may become complicated when the trachea is deviated. In cases of tracheal deviation, the trachea is not in its usual midline position, which can make locating the correct spot for incision more challenging. This difficulty is increased because the trachea's position may not be easily palpable or visible due to its displacement, which can complicate the procedure and increase the risk of complications.

Other Options:

 

Option B. Laryngeal airway: A laryngeal airway (LMA) is inserted above the larynx at the supraglottic level. Since this procedure does not involve the trachea directly, a deviated trachea does not affect the placement of an LMA, making it relatively easy to perform.

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation may become slightly more difficult with tracheal deviation, it usually remains manageable. The main challenge might be encountering some resistance or needing to adjust the angle of the tube. However, with careful maneuvering, the endotracheal tube can still be guided into the trachea.

Option D. Cricothyroidotomy: This procedure involves making an incision through the cricothyroid membrane, located above the trachea at the level of the larynx. Because the tracheal deviation occurs below this point, it does not directly impact the cricothyroidotomy, making it a viable option even with tracheal deviation.

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy can be more challenging in cases of tracheal deviation due to the altered position of the trachea, making the precise location for incision difficult to identify.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for granuloma inguinale? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The causative agent for granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is Calymmatobacterium granulomatis.
  • It is now called Klebsiella granulomatis and is a gram-negative bacillus causing chronic ulcerative infection of the vulva.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes pelvic inflammatory disease

 

Option C. Ureaplasma urealyticum: Causes urethritis

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Causes syphilis

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of thick white vaginal secretions. Which of the following can be used to identify the likely species of the causative agent? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHROMagar

 

The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of candidiasis. CHROMagar can be used for the rapid identification of Candida species. It is based on the fungal enzymatic action on various chromogenic substrates in the medium.

 

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1-4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bird seed agar: Mainly used for the isolation and differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans due to its ability to produce brown colonies owing to phenol oxidase activity.

 

Option B. Brain heart infusion agar: A rich, non-selective medium used for cultivating a variety of fastidious organisms, not specific for differentiating Candida species.

 

Option D. Sabouraud dextrose agar: Commonly used for the culture of fungi but does not differentiate between Candida species as effectively as CHROMagar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHROMagar is the preferred medium for rapidly identifying and differentiating various Candida species directly from clinical specimens like vaginal swabs, with Candida albicans typically forming green colonies on this medium. This tool is essential for quick, accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment of candidiasis.

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NTD

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings typically associated with neural tube defects (NTD), more specifically spina bifida.

 

  • Banana sign: This refers to the excessive curvature of the cerebellum, which appears compressed and curved, resembling a banana.
  • Lemon sign: This is characterized by the pinching of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, causing it to appear like a lemon when viewed from the front. These signs are indicative of the changes in intracranial pressure and structure caused by spina bifida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: This condition involves the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, and is often described as having a "frog-like" face due to the absence of the cranial vault.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome has various ultrasound markers, but these are typically subtle and referred to as soft tissue markers, not including the banana or lemon signs.

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: This condition is characterized by the "double bubble" sign on ultrasound, indicating a blockage in the duodenum, and is not associated with the banana or lemon signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: A lady presented with a pelvic mass which was hyperintense on T1-weighted image, hyperintense on T1-fat saturated image, and hypointense on T2-weighted image with T2 shading. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrioma

 

The imaging findings described are characteristic of an endometrioma. Endometriomas are cystic ovarian lesions filled with old blood, often referred to as "chocolate cysts." On MRI, these lesions typically appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images due to the presence of subacute or chronic blood products. On T1-fat saturated images, the mass remains hyperintense, confirming that the hyperintensity is due to blood rather than fat. The hallmark feature of an endometrioma is the T2 shading sign, which refers to the gradual decrease in signal intensity on T2-weighted images due to repeated hemorrhage and layering of blood products within the cyst.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teratoma: Teratomas often contain fat, which would appear hyperintense on T1-weighted images but would become hypointense on T1-fat saturated sequences. The lack of T2 shading and persistence of T1 hyperintensity on fat saturation sequences make this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option C. Carcinoma ovary: Carcinoma of the ovary usually appears as a solid or complex cystic mass with variable signal characteristics. It does not typically present with T1 hyperintensity due to fat or blood nor does it show T2 shading.

 

Option D. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are solid ovarian tumors that do not exhibit hyperintensity on T1-weighted images or T2 shading. They usually appear as large, solid masses with homogeneous or slightly heterogeneous signal intensities on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriomas are characterized by T1 hyperintensity that persists on T1-fat saturated images and display the T2 shading sign, distinguishing them from other ovarian masses.

questions.text: Which of these methods relies on behavioral sciences? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Management by objective

 

Management by objective (MBO) is a technique based on behavioral sciences. It was developed by Peter Drucker in the 1950s and emphasizes the importance of setting clear goals and objectives that are aligned with organizational goals, and then measuring progress towards achieving those objectives.

 

MBO is based on the idea that individuals are motivated by the achievement of goals and that they perform better when they know what is expected of them. The technique involves a participatory process where employees are involved in setting their own goals and objectives, which are then reviewed and evaluated by their managers. This approach is intended to improve communication and collaboration within organizations, and to help employees feel more engaged and motivated in their work.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decision making:  This can rely on both behavioral sciences and quantitative methods, but in the context of management and organizational processes, it often involves analytical and quantitative approaches.

 

Option B. Systems analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to understand and analyze complex systems and processes, often involving mathematical models and simulations.

 

Option C. Network analysis:  This is a quantitative method used to plan and control complex projects, involving techniques like PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method).

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1

 

  • SGLT-1 is a transporter protein located in the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in the absorption of glucose and sodium from the gut lumen into the enterocytes (intestinal cells). In the context of ORS, SGLT-1 facilitates the absorption of glucose, which helps in the rehydration process by increasing fluid absorption.

 

Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-2 (Sodium-Glucose Transporter 2): SGLT-2 is primarily found in the proximal renal tubules of the kidney and is responsible for the reabsorption of glucose from the urine. It is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. GLUT-4 (Glucose Transporter 4): GLUT-4 is a glucose transporter primarily found in muscle and adipose tissue. It is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into these tissues and is not related to glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. GLUT-2 (Glucose Transporter 2): GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter found in the liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. It is involved in glucose uptake by the liver and pancreas and is not the primary transporter for glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 538

choices.text: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Bronchogenic Carcinoma
Germ cell tumor

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: Microfilariae with sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brugia malayi

 

The most likely organism based on the description of the microfilariae is Brugia malayi.

 

The microfilariae of B. malayi are sheathed and have kinks and secondary curves. The tail tip has two nuclei - a terminal and a subterminal one. It has nocturnal periodicity.

 

The female filarial worms, which belong to the phylum Nematoda, give birth to larvae known as microfilariae.

 

Some of the microfilariae retain their egg membranes and are known as sheathed microfilariae. They can be further differentiated on the basis of the arrangement of nuclei in the tail.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Also causes lymphatic filariasis but does not have two distinct nuclei at the tail tip of its microfilariae.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Known for daytime periodicity and does not show the characteristic two nuclei at the tail tip.

 

Option D. Onchocerca volvulus: Does not circulate in peripheral blood; instead, its microfilariae are found in skin and connective tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of microfilariae with a sheathed tail and two nuclei at the tail tip is a diagnostic feature of Brugia malayi, crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial infections. This morphological detail is important for correct diagnosis and appropriate management of lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active female presents with painful genital ulcers on her vulva and bilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. The ulcers have irregular edges and a soft base. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Key features include:

 

  • Painful genital ulcers
  • Irregular edges with soft base
  • Painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy 
  • These ulcers are typically single rather than multiple, and they have irregular edges with a soft base rather than being fluid-filled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Presents with painless ulcer (chancre) and non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Option C. LGV: Causes painless ulcers with painful lymphadenopathy (buboes)

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Typically presents with multiple, fluid-filled vesicular lesions rather than ulcers with irregular edges

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Chancroid presents with painful genital ulcers having irregular edges and soft base, accompanied by painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows the absence of cranial bones, which are typically visible as white structures on ultrasound. In anencephaly, the forebrain and cranial vault are absent, resulting in a recognizable appearance on ultrasound. Additionally, anencephaly is often associated with prominent eyeballs, known as the "frog eye sign," further supporting this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: This condition presents as a fluid-filled cystic mass, often seen in the neck region. On ultrasound, cystic hygroma appears as a black (anechoic) structure due to its fluid content, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull, usually seen as a sac-like protrusion. This appearance is distinct from anencephaly and involves brain tissue extending outside the cranial cavity, which is not observed here.

 

Option D. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition involves an enlarged posterior fossa with a cystic structure, indicating the presence of a posterior fossa cyst. The ultrasound findings of Dandy Walker malformation are distinct and do not match the current image showing an absence of cranial bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial bones and brain tissue on ultrasound, often accompanied by the "frog eye sign."

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids. He reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food and has significant weight loss over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed. Which radiological sign is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rat-tail sign

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia, a primary motility disorder of the esophagus. 

 

  • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia)
  • The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through
  • Regurgitation of undigested food
  • Weight loss due to feeding difficulties 
  • The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow. 
  • The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corkscrew esophagus: This appearance is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm, a different motility disorder with intermittent dysphagia.

 

Option B. Apple-core lesion: This is typically seen in colonic carcinoma, appearing as a symmetric narrowing with overhanging edges. It's not associated with esophageal disorders.

 

Option C. String sign: This is typically seen in CHPS in the pylorus and TB and Chron’s disease in the ileum and represents narrowing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In achalasia, dysphagia is characteristically worse for liquids than solids due to the underlying motility disorder affecting lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, with bird beak sign and rat tail sign being the characteristic radiological finding on barium swallow.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling below the left earlobe and is experiencing pain. What is the most likely cause of this pain? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Greater auricular nerve

 

The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that supplies the skin of the external ear, the area over the parotid gland, and the angle of the mandible. It is a branch of the cervical plexus, specifically arising from the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3. Any acute inflammation of the gland such as acute sialadenitis results in pain in the preauricular region. The pain is mainly due to stretching of the capsule resulting in stimulation of the greater auricular nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) traverses through the parotid gland but does not innervate it. Instead, it provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression. Damage to the facial nerve may lead to facial paralysis or weakness, but it's not directly responsible for sensation or pain below the earlobe.

 

Option B. Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This is a layer of connective tissue that envelops the neck and extends into the face. It surrounds several structures, including the parotid gland. While the fascia itself isn't directly responsible for sensation, inflammation or infections that cause stretching of this fascia might contribute to discomfort.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal nerve: This is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin above the parotid gland, the external ear, and the external auditory canal. Though it provides sensation to the aforementioned areas, the region described in the scenario (below the earlobe) is not primarily innervated by the auriculotemporal nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Greater auricular nerve originates from the cervical plexus, specifically from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves. It ascends to the parotid gland and provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the earlobe, and the area behind the ear, so the greater auricular nerve is most directly responsible for transmitting pain sensations from these regions.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence 

 

The incident described in the scenario will be tried under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence refers to a disregard for the safety of others that is so gross or extreme that it constitutes a criminal act.

 

Even in emergency, the surgeon should not have performed operation while under the influence of alcohol.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence: In this there is no specific and clear violation of law. Simple absence of care and skill. The trial is conducted in a civil court and typically results in fine as punishment. The negligence described in the scenario is too gross to be considered merely civil negligence.

 

Option C. Therapeutic Misadventure (Medical Maloccurence): Individual is injured or died due to some unintentional Act by a doctor/hospital and is not related to the quality of care provided. It is an unforeseen accident due to individual biological variations. Here no one is negligent.

 

Option D. Dichotomy or Fee Splitting or Sharing: Giving of a commission  by  one  doctor  to  another  for  referring, recommending, or procuring any patients for medical, surgical or other treatment. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by State Medical Council. The punishment can be:

 

  • Warning
  • Penal erasure (professional death sentence).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: A woman with an obstetric score of G2P1 comes to the clinic at 14 weeks of gestation for her antenatal checkup. A uterine artery doppler was suggested by the doctor. What would it detect? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early-onset preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Early-onset preeclampsia:
    • Uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks of gestation can detect markers predictive of early-onset preeclampsia.
    • Raised pulsatility index (PI) in the uterine artery and notching of the uterine artery waveform are indicative markers.
    • Biochemical markers for early-onset preeclampsia include decreased levels of PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, and PlGF, and increased levels of sFlt-1, sEng, and cell-free DNA.
  • Predictors of Preeclampsia:
    • History and Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP):
      • A patient's medical history and MAP are initial predictors.
    • Biophysical Markers:
      • Uterine artery Doppler: Raised PI and notching of the waveform are early indicators.
    • Biochemical Markers:
      • Decreased: PP13, VEGF, PAPPA, PlGF.
      • Increased: sFlt-1, sEng, cell-free DNA.
    • Anti-angiogenic Factors:
      • sFlt-1 and sEng are important markers indicating anti-angiogenic activity, which is associated with preeclampsia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Late-onset preeclampsia: Uterine artery Doppler is more predictive of early-onset rather than late-onset preeclampsia.

 

Option C. Fetal growth restriction: While fetal growth restriction can be associated with preeclampsia, the uterine artery Doppler specifically predicts early-onset preeclampsia rather than fetal growth restriction alone.

 

Option D. Placenta accreta: Uterine artery Doppler is not used to detect placenta accreta. Placenta accreta is typically diagnosed through ultrasound or MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks gestation can predict early-onset preeclampsia by identifying raised pulsatility index (PI) and notching of the uterine artery waveform.

 

Ref: Page no 1818, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. This condition leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons, which can be observed as a cherry red spot in the macula of the retina. However, unlike other sphingolipidoses, Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-Galactosidase and is an X-linked recessive disorder. This condition does not typically present with a cherry red spot and is associated with other symptoms such as angiokeratomas and renal complications.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme β-Glucosidase. It is typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly, and while cherry red spots can rarely be seen, it is not a common feature of the disease. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly distinguishes it from Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I) is not a lysosomal storage disorder or a sphingolipidosis. It is associated with glycogen metabolism and does not present with cherry red spots. This disease also features hepatomegaly, which is not consistent with the condition described in the question.

 

Additional Information

 

  • All sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except for Fabry's disease, which is X-linked recessive.
  • All sphingolipidoses are associated with mental retardation except for Gaucher's disease and Fabry's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have hepatosplenomegaly except for Tay-Sachs and Krabbe's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have a cherry red spot in the eye except for Fabry's and Gaucher's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses with angiokeratoma include GM1 gangliosidosis and Fabry's disease.
  • Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling rheumatoid arthritis or idiopathic juvenile arthritis include Farber's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling sickle cell crisis include Fabry's disease.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.

 

Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: In a patient with Horner syndrome, ptosis is most likely due to paralysis of which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior tarsal muscle

 

The superior tarsal muscle, also known as Muller's muscle, is a smooth muscle that assists in elevating the upper eyelid. In Horner syndrome, there is damage to the sympathetic nerve supply, specifically the T1 nerve, which innervates the superior tarsal muscle. Paralysis of this muscle leads to ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, because the muscle cannot perform its function of aiding eyelid elevation. Horner syndrome typically results from a disruption in the sympathetic nerves, leading to symptoms like ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbitalis: This muscle provides support to the eyeball from the back. In Horner syndrome, although the orbitalis muscle may be affected, leading to a sunken appearance of the eyeball (apparent enophthalmos), it does not contribute directly to ptosis.

 

Option B. Levator superioris palpebrae: This muscle is primarily responsible for the elevation of the eyelid. However, it is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not by the sympathetic nervous system, and its paralysis leads to significant ptosis, but this condition is unrelated to Horner syndrome.

 

Option C. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Paralysis of this muscle leads to inability to close the eyelid but is not involved in ptosis due to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner syndrome is characterized by ptosis due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller's muscle), which is innervated by sympathetic fibers, particularly from the T1 spinal nerve

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CMV

 

In the biopsy image, the characteristic feature to note is the presence of inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm of the cell, giving an appearance often described as "owl eye." This is a hallmark of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV can cause severe infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as patients living with HIV (PLHIV). The virus leads to the formation of large cells with nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause pneumonia, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not produce the distinctive "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in CMV infection.

 

Option C. EBV: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is known for causing infectious mononucleosis and is associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders, but there is no inclusion bodies in the cells.

 

Option D. HSV2: Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2) can cause various infections, including pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, but it does not produce the specific "owl eye" inclusions seen in CMV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is associated with an increased risk of? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

 

Clonorchis sinensis

 


The life cycle of Clonorchis sinensis is given below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Cancer: Mainly associated with Human Papillomavirus (HPV) types 16 and 18.

 

Option C. Gastric Carcinoma: Most commonly linked with Helicobacter pylori infection.

 

Option D. Bladder Carcinoma: Associated with Schistosoma haematobium infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is primarily associated with an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, emphasizing the importance of avoiding consumption of undercooked freshwater fish in endemic areas to prevent this parasitic infection.
