questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival" in CPR? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

The Chain of Survival is a series of critical steps that improve survival in cardiac arrest cases. The American Heart Association (AHA) recently updated the chain by adding a sixth link: Recovery.

 

Updated Chain of Survival: (Out of hospital cardiac arrest)

 

  1. Early recognition and activation of emergency response system
  2. Early CPR with high-quality chest compressions
  3. Rapid defibrillation
  4. Advanced resuscitation by emergency medical services (EMS)
  5. Post-cardiac arrest care in a hospital setting
  6. Recovery phase for physical and emotional rehabilitation

 

 

The Recovery phase focuses on post-resuscitation care, including physical rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up to improve the patient’s quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early CPR: CPR is already part of the existing chain but is not the newly added sixth link.

 

Option B. Post-cardiac arrest care: This is an essential part of the chain but was already included before the update.

 

Option C. Post MI care: Management after a myocardial infarction (MI) is important but not specific to cardiac arrest care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) has updated the Chain of Survival to include a sixth link: Recovery. This emphasizes the importance of post-cardiac arrest rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure often seen in aplastic anemia, involves the failure of the bone marrow to produce sufficient blood cells. The spleen is not involved in this pathology, so splenectomy would not be beneficial. The problem lies within the bone marrow, not the spleen, making splenectomy contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Splenic rupture: Splenectomy is commonly indicated in cases of splenic rupture, whether due to trauma or iatrogenic causes, to prevent life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: In cases of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), splenectomy can be an effective treatment option to achieve durable remission, although it is not the first-line treatment.

 

  • Corticosteroids and other treatments are often tried first.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia: Splenectomy may be indicated in hairy cell leukemia in cases of massive splenomegaly or persistent cytopenias to alleviate symptoms and improve blood counts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

questions.text: The defined population norm for Urban-Primary health centre in our country is one such centre per: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 per 50,000

 

In India, the population norm for establishing a UPHC is one center per 50,000 population. These centers are intended to provide primary healthcare services in urban areas, addressing the healthcare needs of urban populations efficiently.

 

The UPHCs are equipped to deliver a range of health services, including preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative care.

 

In UPHC, one Urban Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) per 10,000 population, and one Urban Social Health Activist (USHA) per 1,000 to 2,500 population.

 

Remember –

 

Population norm for rural PHC

 

  • 1 per 30,000 populations in plain area
  • 1 per 20,000 populations in tribal and hilly areas

 

Educational Objective:

 

The population norm for establishing an Urban Primary Health Centre (UPHC) in India is one center per 50,000 populations.

questions.text: Identify the type of ulcer. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trophic ulcer

 

The image shows an ulcer on the sole of the foot with a characteristic appearance. It is surrounded by a white area due to callosities, indicating chronic pressure. This description is typical of a trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer. These ulcers occur in areas of the body subjected to prolonged pressure, often in patients with peripheral neuropathy. The lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and subsequent ulceration, which is commonly seen in the weight-bearing areas such as the soles of the feet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial ulcer: Arterial ulcers are typically located on the distal parts of the body such as the tips of toes and feet. They are often painful, with a "punched-out" appearance and a well-defined border. They usually have minimal exudate and occur due to inadequate blood supply.

 

Option B. Venous ulcer: Venous ulcers generally occur on the lower legs, particularly around the medial malleolus. They have irregular borders, are usually surrounded by hyperpigmentation, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These ulcers are often exudative and less painful compared to arterial ulcers.

 

Option D. Diabetic ulcer: While diabetic ulcers can have a neuropathic component, they are a more complex condition with additional ischemic and infectious components. They are not exclusively located on pressure points and can appear anywhere on the foot. The distinguishing factor for trophic ulcers is their location on weight-bearing areas with surrounding callosities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trophic (neuropathic) ulcers typically occur in weight-bearing areas, such as the soles of the feet, and are surrounded by callosities. They are primarily seen in patients with peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation leads to repeated trauma and ulceration. Recognizing this type of ulcer is crucial for appropriate management and prevention of further complications.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus underwent a prosthetic valve replacement surgery 4 weeks ago. She now presents with fever, fatigue, and a new murmur on examination. Blood cultures reveal the causative organism. Which is the most likely causative agent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staph epidermidis

 

This is a case of early prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE) occurring within 4 weeks of valve replacement surgery. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early PVE, characterized by its occurrence within one year of surgery. The mnemonic "E for Early, E for Epidermidis" helps remember this association. Additionally, S. epidermidis is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis regardless of timing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterococcus: While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most common cause of early prosthetic valve endocarditis. It is more commonly associated with nosocomial urinary tract infections.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: S. aureus commonly seen in native valve endocarditis, particularly in patients with underlying valve disease.

 

Option D. Streptococcus viridans: This organism is typically associated with late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring after one year of valve replacement).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common causative organism in early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurring within one year of valve replacement) and is also the overall most common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A male bartender, following a fight was brought to the emergency with respiratory distress. On clinical evaluation, the breath sounds were absent with increased resonance on right side, and tracheal deviation on the left side was noted. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Traumatic Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features point to traumatic pneumothorax:

 

  • History of trauma (fight)
  • Respiratory distress
  • Absent breath sounds on one side (indicates collapsed lung)
  • Tracheal deviation to opposite side

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collapse of lung: Incorrect as collapse is a consequence of pneumothorax, not the primary diagnosis. Additionally, isolated collapse without pneumothorax doesn't cause increased resonance

 

Option C. Pleural effusion: Incorrect as pleural effusion develops gradually, gives dull percussion note and doesn't typically cause tracheal deviation unless massive

 

Option D. Consolidation of lung: Incorrect as consolidation shows increased vocal resonance, bronchial breathing and doesn't cause tracheal deviation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Traumatic pneumothorax presents with respiratory distress, absent breath sounds on affected side and possible tracheal deviation after trauma.

questions.text: A patient presented with strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses with chest x-ray showing rib notching. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation of Aorta

 

The classic presentation of coarctation of the aorta, a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta. This narrowing typically occurs just after the arteries that branch off to the upper body, leading to a disparity in blood flow and pressure between the upper and lower parts of the body.

 

Key indicators in this case include:

 

  1. Strong upper limb pulses and weak lower limb pulses: The narrowing restricts blood flow to the lower extremities, causing the upper body to receive a higher volume of blood, which results in stronger pulses in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs.
  2. Chest x-ray showing rib notching: Rib notching is a result of enlarged intercostal arteries that form collateral pathways to bypass the narrowed aorta. These arteries erode the underside of the ribs over time, creating a notched appearance on chest x-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transposition of great vessels: This condition involves the switching of the major arteries (the aorta and the pulmonary artery) from their normal positions. It does not present with rib notching or a difference in pulse strength between the upper and lower limbs.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot: This is a combination of four heart defects, including a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It primarily presents with cyanosis and does not typically involve rib notching or differential limb pulses.

 

Option D. Ebstein’s anomaly: This is a rare heart defect affecting the tricuspid valve and right ventricle. It does not cause rib notching or a significant difference in pulse strength between upper and lower limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta is identified by the presence of strong upper limb pulses, weak lower limb pulses, and rib notching on a chest x-ray, which is caused by collateral circulation developing around the narrowed section of the aorta.

questions.text: The treatment given to the patient presenting with a history of binge alcohol intake and symptoms of convulsions, altered sensorium, and plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiamine followed by dextrose


In patients with a history of chronic alcohol intake, thiamine deficiency is a common complication. Alcohol interferes with thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to deficiencies that can impact various metabolic processes, including carbohydrate metabolism. Thiamine is a crucial cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA during glucose metabolism. Administering glucose without prior thiamine can precipitate acute thiamine deficiency symptoms, worsening the patient’s condition and potentially leading to Wernicke’s encephalopathy, a severe neurological disorder.

 

Therefore, in cases where hypoglycemia is present (as indicated by a plasma glucose level of 45 mg/dL), the correct management is to first administer thiamine to replenish depleted stores and then follow with dextrose to correct the hypoglycemia safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25% dextrose: While dextrose is necessary to treat hypoglycemia, administering it before thiamine in a thiamine-deficient patient can worsen the deficiency, leading to serious neurological complications.

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This is used in the treatment of methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, not relevant in alcohol-induced hypoglycemia or thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine: While thiamine is part of the treatment, it alone does not correct hypoglycemia. Both thiamine and dextrose are necessary, in the correct order.

 

Educational Objective:


In alcohol-related hypoglycemia, always administer thiamine before dextrose to prevent the exacerbation of thiamine deficiency and associated complications.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, typically presenting with symptoms such as muscle weakness, paralysis, and respiratory failure rather than rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option C. Clostridium perfringens: Associated with gastroenteritis that causes abdominal cramps and diarrhea, typically occurring 8-16 hours after consumption of contaminated food.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, characterized by prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and other systemic symptoms, rather than immediate vomiting.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option D. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

questions.text: A patient has throbbing unilateral headache and photophobia, which is treated by sumatriptan. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Migraine

 

Explanation:

 

Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headache often associated with photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), nausea, and vomiting. Symptoms of "throbbing unilateral headache with photophobia" are classic presentation of migraine.

 

Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist are the drug of choice for acute severe migraine attacks. They work by:

 

  • Causing vasoconstriction of blood vessels in the brain
  • Inhibiting the release of inflammatory neuropeptides, particularly Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Incorrect because. Tension headaches typically present as bilateral, non-pulsatile, "band-like" pain around the head. They are usually not associated with photophobia and are not typically treated with triptans like sumatriptan. First-line treatments for tension headaches are NSAIDs.

 

Option C. Cluster headache: Incorrect because. Cluster headaches, while unilateral, are extremely severe and often described as "boring" or "stabbing" rather than throbbing. They are typically associated with ipsilateral autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal congestion, or rhinorrhoea. While triptans can be used for cluster headaches, first-line treatments usually include high-flow oxygen therapy.

 

Option D. Frontal headache: Incorrect because. "Frontal headache" refers to pain localized to the frontal region of the head and can be a symptom of various conditions including sinusitis, tension headache, or migraine. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of acute attack:

 

  • Drug of choice for mild to moderate headache – NSAIDs (Paracetamol, diclofenac)
  • Drug of choice for Acute severe attack – Triptans
  • Other drug for Acute severe migraine – Ergotamine

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spontaneous respiratory effort

 

  • The capnograph shows a characteristic pattern known as the curare notch or curare cleft.
  • This pattern indicates spontaneous inspiratory effort by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation.
  • This occurs when the patient attempts to breathe against the ventilator cycle, causing a dip in the capnograph waveform.
  • The appropriate next step would be to paralyze the patient again by administering an additional dose of muscle relaxant to ensure proper synchronization with the ventilator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal intubation: In cases of esophageal intubation, the capnograph typically shows a very low or absent end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) reading because the endotracheal tube is not in the trachea, leading to little to no CO2 being detected. The waveform would be almost flat.

 

 

Option B. Inspiration with cardiac oscillations: Cardiac oscillations can appear on the capnograph as small oscillations or ripples on the expiratory plateau due to the beating of the heart causing minor fluctuations in airway pressure. This is not characterized by a distinct cleft or notch.

 

 

Option C. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm causes a "shark fin" appearance on the capnograph due to obstructed airflow and prolonged expiration. The waveform would show a slanted, rather than a squared-off, expiratory plateau.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A curare notch or cleft on a capnograph indicates spontaneous respiratory effort in a patient who is supposed to be fully ventilated under muscle relaxants, requiring re-administration of the muscle relaxant to ensure proper mechanical ventilation.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1311

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: True about Warburg effect?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aerobic glycolysis with lactate formation

 

This is the correct statement. The Warburg effect is characterized by cancer cells utilizing glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen (aerobic glycolysis), leading to the production of lactate. This metabolic shift is a hallmark of many cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Makes cancer cells immortal: This statement is not true. The Warburg effect is a metabolic phenomenon observed in many cancer cells where they preferentially use glycolysis to generate energy, but it does not make cancer cells immortal. Immortality of cancer cells is typically associated with mutations that allow them to evade normal cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.

 

Option C. Produce more ATP: This statement is not true in the context of the Warburg effect. While glycolysis is less efficient at producing ATP compared to oxidative phosphorylation (which occurs in the mitochondria), cancer cells under the Warburg effect primarily generate ATP through glycolysis, which is less efficient but provides other metabolic advantages to rapidly dividing cancer cells.

 

Option D. Decrease glucose uptake: This statement is not true. Cancer cells under the Warburg effect often increase their glucose uptake to meet their high energy demands through glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warburg effect

 

  • This effect occurs in cancerous cells. This is a paradox from normal in the sense that Cancer cells convert pyruvate to lactate even in the presence of O2. This is known as aerobic glycolysis.
  • Energy derived from conversion of pyruvate to lactate is just 2 ATPs, hence rapidly growing cancer cells take up large amount of glucose compared to normal cells. Due to large amount of glucose used, patients have Cachexia (weight loss).

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 738

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

 

The image shows an amputation where both the tibia and fibula are visible below the knee, which indicates a below-knee amputation. A dissected specimen of the tibia and fibula below the knee was shown, which matches the image provided. Below-knee amputations involve removing the lower limb while preserving the knee joint, improving the potential for prosthetic use and mobility in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Above knee amputation: This amputation occurs above the knee joint, where the entire knee and part of the femur are removed. However, the image does not show the knee joint being amputated.

 

Option C. Chopart’s amputation: This type of amputation occurs in the intertarsal region of the foot, which is not applicable in this image, as the amputation is clearly higher up, below the knee.

 

Option D. Lisfranc amputation: This refers to an amputation at the tarsometatarsal joint, which is also a lower limb amputation but located in the foot. The image shows an amputation above the foot, making this option incorrect.

 

Different types of amputations:

 

  1. Hip disarticulation: Removal at the hip joint (disarticulation from the joint).
  2. Above knee amputation: Removal above the knee.
  3. Knee disarticulation: Amputation through the knee joint.
  4. Below knee amputation: Removal below the knee.
  5. Syme's amputation: Amputation above the ankle.
  6. Boyd's or Pirogov amputation: Involves cutting the calcaneum (heel bone).
  7. Chopart's amputation: Involves the intertarsal area (just above the calcaneum).
  8. Lisfranc's amputation: Involves the tarsometatarsal joint (between the tarsal and metatarsal bones).
  9. Transmetatarsal amputation: Amputation in between the metatarsal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A below-knee amputation involves the removal of the lower limb below the knee joint, preserving the knee, tibia, and fibula, which improves mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic SDH

 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is characterized by a hypodense (dark) appearance on CT scans due to the older age of the blood collection, which becomes less dense over time. The hallmark shape of a subdural hematoma is crescent-shaped or moon-like, indicating that the bleed is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid membrane, spreading widely along the brain’s surface.

 

In this image:

 

  • The hypodense (dark) appearance confirms that the bleed is chronic.
  • The crescent shape seen in the scan is typical for a subdural hematoma (SDH).

 

These findings are classic for a chronic SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute EDH (Epidural Hematoma): Acute EDH appears as a biconvex (lens-shaped) collection that is hyperdense (bright) on imaging due to fresh bleeding. It is not crescent-shaped and does not appear hypodense as seen in this image.

 

Option B. Chronic EDH: Chronic EDH is rare and still appears biconvex, like acute EDH. The imaging features shown here do not match EDH patterns.

 

Option D. Acute SDH: Acute SDH appears hyperdense (bright) because the blood is fresh and denser. It is crescent-shaped but does not match the hypodense characteristics of a chronic bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A crescent or moon-shaped, hypodense (dark) collection on a CT scan suggests a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder. The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature. Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D. Delusional disorder: The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with severe nodulocystic acne involving the face and back, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isotretinoin

 

This is a case of grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne, which is the most severe form of acne vulgaris. In grade 4 acne:

 

  • Patients present with deep nodules and cysts
  • Lesions are typically present on face and back
  • Treatment choice is oral isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)
  • Dosage: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day with total cumulative dose of 120-150 mg/kg
  • Isotretinoin requires monitoring of lipid profile and liver function tests.

 

Oral isotretinoin is the treatment of choice for severe nodulocystic acne due to its ability to target all four pathophysiological factors of acne:

 

  1. Reduces sebum production by shrinking sebaceous glands.
  2. Inhibits follicular keratinization, preventing comedone formation.
  3. Exerts anti-inflammatory effects.
  4. Reduces the population of Propionibacterium acnes, the bacteria involved in acne pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prednisolone/Steroids

 

  • Systemic steroids are not indicated for routine acne treatment
  • Can actually worsen acne on withdrawal
  • May have role in severe inflammatory acne but not as monotherapy

 

Option C. Topical tretinoin

 

  • Only indicated for grade 1 (comedonal) acne
  • Used along with topical antibiotics in grade 2 acne
  • Insufficient for severe nodulocystic acne

 

Option D. Azithromycin

 

  • Oral antibiotics like azithromycin are used in grade 3 acne
  • Not potent enough for severe nodulocystic lesions
  • Oral Minocycline, Azithromycin and Doxycycline can be used in grade 3 acne

 

Grades of Acne:

 

  1. Grade 1 : Non-inflammatory open and closed comedones. Treated with topical retinoids (Tretinoin, Adapalene).
  2. Grade 2 (Mild inflammatory acne): Presence of papules and mild erythema. Treated with topical retinoids + topical antibiotics (Clindamycin, Nadifloxacin).
  3. Grade 3 (Moderate inflammatory acne): Predominance of pustules. Treated with topical retinoids + oral antibiotics (Minocycline, Azithromycin, Doxycycline).
  4. Grade 4 (Severe nodulocystic acne): Deep, painful nodules and cysts on the face, chest, and back. Treatment of choice: Oral isotretinoin.

 

Educational Objective:


Oral isotretinoin is the drug of choice for grade 4 (nodulocystic) acne vulgaris.
